[[Velar consonant|Velar]]/<br/>[[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! colspan="3" | [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA link|m}} | {{IPA link|n}} | | {{IPA link|ŋ}} | |- ! rowspan="2" colspan="2" | [[Plosive consonant|Plosive]] ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|fortis]]}} | {{IPA link|p}} | {{IPA link|t}} | | {{IPA link|k}} | ({{IPA link|ʔ}}) |- ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|lenis]]}} | {{IPA link|b}} | {{IPA link|d}} | | {{IPA link|ɡ}} | |- ! rowspan="2" colspan="2" | [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|fortis]]}} | {{IPA link|p͡f}} | {{IPA link|t͡s}} | {{IPA link|t͡ʃ}} | | |- ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|lenis]]}} | | | ({{IPA link|d͡ʒ}}) | | |- ! rowspan="4" | [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ! rowspan="2" | {{small|[[sibilant]]}} ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|fortis]]}} | | {{IPA link|s}} | {{IPA link|ʃ}} | | |- ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|lenis]]}} | | {{IPA link|z}} | ({{IPA link|ʒ}}) | | |- ! rowspan="2" | {{small|non-sibilant}} ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|fortis]]}} | {{IPA link|f}} | ({{IPA link|θ}}) | {{IPA link|ç}} | {{IPA link|x}} | {{IPA link|h}} |- ! {{small|[[Fortis and lenis|lenis]]}} | {{IPA link|v}} | ({{IPA link|ð}}) | {{IPA link|ʝ|j}} | | |- ! colspan="3" | [[Lateral consonant|Lateral]] | | {{IPA link|l}} | | | |- ! colspan="3" | [[Rhotic consonant|Rhotic]] | | colspan="3" | {{IPA|r}} | |}
:'''''Notes''''' *{{IPA|/p͡f/}} is bilabial–labiodental {{IPA|[p͡f]}}, rather than purely labiodental {{IPA|[p̪͡f]}}.<ref name="MangoldPF">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=45}}</ref> *{{IPA|/t, d, l, n/}} can be [[Apical consonant|apical]] alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t|t̺}}, {{IPAlink|d|d̺}}, {{IPAlink|l|l̺}}, {{IPAlink|n|n̺}}]}},<ref name="coronalsa">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|pp=47, 49}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=94, 96}}. According to this source, only {{IPA|/l, n/}} can be apical alveolar.</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|pp=51–52, 84}}. According to this source, only {{IPA|/t, n/}} can be apical alveolar.</ref><ref>See the x-ray tracing of {{IPA|/l/}} in {{Harvcoltxt|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996|p=184}}, based on data from {{Harvcoltxt|Wängler|1961}}.</ref> [[Laminal consonant|laminal]] alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t|t̻}}, {{IPAlink|d|d̻}}, {{IPAlink|l|l̻}}, {{IPAlink|n|n̻}}]}}<ref name="coronalsa"/><ref name="coronalsa-krech">{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=90, 94, 96}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|pp=51–52, 84}}. According to this source, only {{IPA|/t, n/}} can be laminal alveolar.</ref> or laminal [[Denti-alveolar consonant|denti-alveolar]] {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t̪}}, {{IPAlink|d̪}}, {{IPAlink|l̪}}, {{IPAlink|n̪}}]}}.<ref name="coronalsa"/><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|p=90}}. According to this source, only {{IPA|/t, d/}} can be laminal denti-alveolar.</ref><ref name="coronalsa-pl">{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|pp=51–52, 59, 78, 84}}</ref><ref>See the x-ray tracing of {{IPA|/t/}} in {{Harvcoltxt|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996|p=184}}, based on data from {{Harvcoltxt|Wängler|1961}}.</ref> The other possible pronunciation of {{IPA|/d/}} that has been reported to occur in unstressed intervocalic positions is retroflex {{IPAblink|ɖ}}.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Hamann|Fuchs|2010|pp=14–24}}</ref> Austrian German often uses the laminal denti-alveolar articulation. **{{IPA|/l/}} is always [[clear l|clear {{IPA|[l]}}]], as in most [[Irish English]] accents. A few Austrian accents may use a [[dark l|velarized {{IPA|[ɫ]}}]] instead, but that is considered non-standard. *In the Standard Austrian variety, {{IPA|/k/}} may be affricated to {{IPAblink|k͡x}} before front vowels.<ref name="moosjipa341">{{Harvcoltxt|Moosmüller|Schmid|Brandstätter|2015|p=341}}</ref> *{{IPA|/t͡s, s, z/}} can be laminal alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t͡s|t̻͡s̻}}, {{IPAlink|s|s̻}}, {{IPAlink|z|z̻}}]}},<ref name="coronalsb">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|pp=50, 52}}</ref><ref name="coronalsb-krech">{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=79–80}}. This source talks only about {{IPA|/s, z/}}.</ref><ref name="coronalsb-pl">{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|pp=65, 75}} This source talks only about {{IPA|/s, z/}}.</ref> laminal post-dental {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t̪͡s̪}}, {{IPAlink|s̪}}, {{IPAlink|z̪}}]}}<ref name="coronalsb"/><ref name="coronalsb-pl"/> (i.e. fronted alveolar, articulated with the blade of the tongue just behind upper front teeth),<ref name="coronalsb"/> or even apical alveolar {{IPA|[{{IPAlink|t͡s|t̺͡s̺}}, {{IPAlink|s̺}}, {{IPAlink|z̺}}]}}.<ref name="coronalsb"/><ref name="coronalsb-krech"/><ref name="coronalsb-pl"/> Austrian German often uses the post-dental articulation. {{IPA|/s, z/}} are always strongly fricated.<ref name="coronalsc">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=50}}</ref> *{{IPA|/t͡ʃ, d͡ʒ, ʃ, ʒ/}} are strongly [[labialization|labialized]] [[Palato-alveolar consonant|palato-alveolar]] sibilants {{IPA|[{{IPA link|t͡ʃ}}ʷ, {{IPA link|d͡ʒ}}ʷ, {{IPA link|ʃ}}ʷ, {{IPA link|ʒ}}ʷ]}}.<ref name="MangoldPA">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|pp=51–52}}</ref><ref name="KrechPA">{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=51–52}}</ref><ref name="MorciniecPA">{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|pp=67, 76}}</ref> {{IPA|/ʃ, ʒ/}} are fricated more weakly than {{IPA|/s, z/}}.<ref name="mangold51">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=51}}</ref> There are two variants of these sounds: **Laminal,<ref name="MangoldPA"/><ref name="MorciniecPA"/> articulated with the foremost part of the blade of the tongue approaching the foremost part of the hard palate, with the tip of the tongue resting behind either upper or lower front teeth.<ref name="MangoldPA"/> **Apico-laminal,<ref name="MangoldPA"/><ref name="KrechPA"/><ref name="MorciniecPA"/> articulated with the tip of the tongue approaching the gums and the foremost part of the blade approaching the foremost part of the hard palate.<ref name="MangoldPA"/> According to {{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005}}, this variant is used more frequently.<ref name="MorciniecPA"/> *{{IPA|/θ, ð/}} are used only in loanwords, mostly from English, such as {{lang|de|Thriller}} {{IPA|/ˈθʁɪlɐ/}},<ref name="coronalsc"/> though some speakers substitute {{IPA|/θ/}} with any of {{IPA|/t, s, f/}} and {{IPA|/ð/}} with any of {{IPA|/d, z, v/}}. There are two variants of these sounds: ** Apical post-dental,<ref name="coronalsc"/> articulated with the tip of the tongue approaching the upper incisors.<ref name="coronalsc"/> ** Apical interdental,<ref name="coronalsc"/> articulated with the tip of the tongue between the upper and lower incisors.<ref name="coronalsc"/> *{{IPA|/r/}} has a number of possible realizations: ** Voiced apical coronal trill/tap {{IPA|[{{IPA link|r|r̺}}, {{IPA link|ɾ|ɾ̺}}]}},<ref name="coronalsd">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=53}}</ref><ref name="coronalsd-krech">{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|p=86}}</ref><ref name="coronalsd-pl">{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|p=79}}</ref> either alveolar (articulated with the tip of the tongue against the alveolar ridge),<ref name="coronalsd"/><ref name="coronalsd-krech"/><ref name="coronalsd-pl"/> or dental (articulated with the tip of the tongue against the back of the upper front teeth).<ref name="coronalsd"/><ref name="coronalsd-krech"/> *** Distribution: Common in the south (Bavaria and many parts of Switzerland and Austria), but it is also found in some speakers in central and northern Germany, especially the elderly. It is also one of possible realizations of {{IPA|/r/}} in the Standard Austrian accent, but a more common alveolar realization is an approximant {{IPAblink|ɹ}}. Even more common are uvular realizations, fricatives {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ʁ}} ~ {{IPA link|χ}}]}} and a trill {{IPAblink|ʀ}}.<ref name="moosjipa341342">{{Harvcoltxt|Moosmüller|Schmid|Brandstätter|2015|pp=341–342}}: "SAG features a wide variety of realizations of the trill. In approximately the past 40 years, the pronunciation norm has changed from an alveolar to a uvular trill. The latter is mostly pronounced as a fricative, either voiced or voiceless. Alveolar trills are still in use, mostly pronounced as an approximant.</ref> ** Voiced uvular trill {{IPAblink|ʀ}},<ref name="coronalsd"/><ref name="coronalsd-krech"/><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|p=80}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996|pp=225, 229}}</ref> which can be realized as voiceless {{IPAblink|ʀ̥}} after voiceless consonants (as in {{lang|de|t'''r'''eten}}).<ref name="coronalsd-krech"/> According to {{Harvcoltxt|Lodge|2009}} it is often a [[Tap consonant|tap]] {{IPAblink|ʀ̆}} intervocalically (as in {{lang|de|Eh'''r'''e}}).<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Lodge|2009|p=46}}</ref> *** Distribution: Occurs in some conservative varieties - most speakers with a uvular {{IPA|/r/}} realize it as a fricative or an approximant.<ref name="SOWL225">{{Harvcoltxt|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996|p=225}}</ref> It is also one of possible realizations of {{IPA|/r/}} in the Standard Austrian accent, but it is less common than a fricative {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ʁ}} ~ {{IPA link|χ}}]}}.<ref name="moosjipa341342"/> ** Dorsal continuant, about the quality of which there is not a complete agreement: *** {{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009}} describe two fricative variants, namely [[Voiced palatal fricative|post-palatal]] {{IPA|[ɣ˖]}} and [[Voiced velar fricative|velar]] {{IPA|[ɣ]}}. The post-palatal variant appears before and after [[front vowel]]s, while the velar variant is used in all other positions.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=74, 85}}</ref> *** {{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005}} describe it as [[Voiced velar fricative|voiced post-velar fricative]] {{IPA|[ʁ̟]}}.<ref name="Morciniec 2005 81">{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|p=81}}</ref> *** {{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005}} and {{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1999}} describe it as [[voiced uvular fricative]] {{IPA|[ʁ]}};<ref name="coronalsd"/><ref name="Kohler86">{{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1999|p=86}}</ref> **** {{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005}} states that "with educated professional radio and TV announcers, as with professional actors on the stage and in film, the [voiced uvular] fricative [realization of] {{IPA|/r/}} clearly predominates."<ref name="coronalsd"/> ***** In the Standard Austrian accent, the uvular fricative is also the most common realization, although its voicing is variable (that is, it can be either voiced {{IPAblink|ʁ}} or voiceless {{IPAblink|χ}}).<ref name="moosjipa341342"/> **** {{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1999}} writes that "the place of articulation of the consonant varies from uvular in e.g. {{lang|de|rot}} ('red') to velar in e.g. {{lang|de|treten}} ('kick'), depending on back or front vowel contexts." He also notes that {{IPAblink|ʁ}} is devoiced after voiceless plosives and fricatives, especially those within the same word, giving the word {{lang|de|treten}} as an example. According to this author, {{IPA|[ʁ]}} can be reduced to an approximant in an intervocalic position.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1999|pp=86–87}}</ref> *** {{Harvcoltxt|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996}} describe it as a uvular fricative {{IPA|[ʁ]}} or approximant {{IPA|[ʁ̞]}}. The latter is less likely to occur word-initially.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Ladefoged|Maddieson|1996|pp=225, 233–234}}</ref> *** Distribution: Almost all areas apart from Bavaria and parts of Switzerland. ** Near-open central unrounded vowel {{IPAblink|ɐ}} is a post-vocalic allophone of (mostly dorsal) varieties of {{IPA|/r/}}. The non-syllabic variant of it is not always near-open or central; it is similar to either {{IPAblink|ɑ}} or {{IPAblink|ə}}, depending on the environment.<ref name="Morciniec 2005 81"/> *** Distribution: Widespread, but less common in Switzerland. *The voiceless stops {{IPAslink|p}}, {{IPAslink|t}}, {{IPAslink|k}} are [[Aspiration (phonetics)|aspirated]] except when preceded by a [[sibilant]]. Many southern dialects do not aspirate {{IPA|/p t k/}}, and some northern ones do so only in a stressed position. The voiceless affricates {{IPA|/p͡f/}}, {{IPA|/t͡s/}}, and {{IPA|/t͡ʃ/}} are never aspirated,<ref name="coronalse">{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=52}}</ref> and neither are any other consonants besides the aforementioned {{IPA|/p, t, k/}}.<ref name="coronalse"/> *The obstruents {{IPA|/b, d, ɡ, z, ʒ, dʒ/}} are voiceless lenis {{IPA|[b̥, d̥, ɡ̊, z̥, ʒ̊, d͜ʒ̊]}} in southern varieties, and they contrast with voiceless fortis {{IPA|[p, t, k, s, ʃ, t͡ʃ]}}. *In Austria, [[intervocalic]] {{IPA|/b, d, ɡ/}} can be lenited to fricatives {{IPA|[{{IPA link|β}}, {{IPA link|ð}}, {{IPA link|ɣ}}]}}.<ref name="moosjipa341"/><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Moosmüller|2007|p=6}}</ref> *Before and after front vowels ({{IPA|/ɪ, iː, ʏ, yː, ɛ, ɛː, eː, œ, øː/}} and, in varieties that realize them as front, {{IPA|/a/}} and/or {{IPA|/aː/}}), the velar consonants {{IPA|/ŋ, k, ɡ/}} are realized as post-palatal {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ŋ˖}}, {{IPA link|k̟}}, {{IPA link|ɡ˖}}]}}.<ref name="wiese-velarpoa">{{Harvcoltxt|Wiese|1996|p=271}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=49, 92, 97}}</ref> According to {{Harvcoltxt|Wiese|1996}}, in a parallel process, {{IPA|/k, ɡ/}} before and after back vowels ({{IPA|/ʊ, uː, ɔ, oː/}} and, in varieties that realize them as back, {{IPA|/a/}} and/or {{IPA|/aː/}}) are retracted to post-velar {{IPA|[{{IPA link|k̠}}, {{IPA link|ɡ˗}}]}} or even uvular {{IPA|[{{IPA link|q}}, {{IPA link|ɢ}}]}}.<ref name="wiese-velarpoa"/> *There is no complete agreement about the nature of {{IPA|/j/}}; it has been variously described as a fricative {{IPAblink|ʝ}},<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Krech|Stock|Hirschfeld|Anders|2009|pp=83–84}}</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Morciniec|Prędota|2005|pp=77–78}}. The authors transcribe it {{IPA|/j/}}, i.e. as an approximant.</ref><ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Wiese|1996|p=12}}. The author transcribes it {{IPA|/j/}}, i.e. as an approximant.</ref> a fricative, which can be fricated less strongly than {{IPA|/ç/}},<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=51}}. The author transcribes it {{IPA|/j/}}, i.e. as an approximant.</ref> a sound variable between a weak fricative an approximant<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Hall|2003|p=48}}. The author transcribes it {{IPA|/j/}}, i.e. as an approximant.</ref> and an approximant {{IPAblink|j}},<ref name="Kohler86"/><ref name="moosjipa340">{{Harvcoltxt|Moosmüller|Schmid|Brandstätter|2015|p=340}}. The authors transcribe it as {{IPA|/j/}}, i.e. as an approximant.</ref> which is the usual realization in the Standard Austrian variety.<ref name="moosjipa340"/> *In many varieties of standard German, {{IPAblink|ʔ}} occurs in careful speech before word stems that begin with a vowel. Some varieties of standard German do not have {{IPA|[ʔ]}}, e.g. [[Swiss Standard German]]. It is not usually considered a phoneme. In colloquial and dialectal speech, {{IPA|[ʔ]}} is often omitted, especially when the word beginning with a vowel is unstressed. *The phonemic status of affricates is controversial. The majority view accepts {{IPAslink|p͡f}} and {{IPAslink|t͡s}}, but not {{IPAslink|t͡ʃ}} or the non-native {{IPAslink|d͡ʒ}}; some<ref>e.g. {{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1990}}</ref> accept none, some accept all but {{IPAslink|d͡ʒ}}, and some<ref>e.g. {{Harvcoltxt|Wiese|1996}}</ref> accept all. {{IPAblink|d͡ʒ}} and {{IPAblink|ʒ}} occur only in words of foreign origin. In certain varieties, they are replaced by {{IPAblink|t͡ʃ}} and {{IPAblink|ʃ}} altogether. *{{IPAblink|ʋ}} is occasionally considered to be an allophone of {{IPAslink|v}}, especially in southern varieties of German. *{{IPAblink|ç}} and {{IPAblink|x}} are traditionally regarded as allophones after front vowels and back vowels, respectively. For a more detailed analysis see below at [[#Ich-Laut and ach-Laut|''ich-Laut'' and ''ach-Laut'']]. According to some analyses, {{IPAblink|χ}} is an allophone of {{IPAslink|x}} after {{IPA|/a, aː/}} and according to some also after {{IPA|/ʊ, ɔ, aʊ̯/}}.<ref name="Kohler88"/><ref name="moosjipa341"/> However, according to {{Harvcoltxt|Moosmüller|Schmid|Brandstätter|2015}}, the uvular allophone is used after {{IPA|/ɔ/}} only in the Standard Austrian variety.<ref name="moosjipa341"/> *Some phonologists{{Who|date=December 2010}} deny the phoneme {{IPAslink|ŋ}} and use {{IPA|/nɡ/}} instead along with {{IPA|/nk/}} instead of {{IPA|/ŋk/}}. The phoneme sequence {{IPA|/nɡ/}} is realized as {{IPA|[ŋɡ]}} when {{IPAslink|ɡ}} can start a valid onset of the next syllable whose nucleus is a vowel other than unstressed {{IPAslink|ə}}, {{IPAslink|ɪ}}, or {{IPAslink|ʊ}}. It becomes {{IPAblink|ŋ}} otherwise. For example: **{{lang|de|Diphthong}} {{IPA|/ˈdɪftɔnɡ/ [ˈdɪftɔŋ]}} **{{lang|de|diphthongieren}} {{IPA|/dɪftɔnˈɡiːʁən/ [ˌdɪftɔŋˈɡiːʁən]}} **{{lang|de|Englisch}} {{IPA|/ˈɛnɡlɪʃ/ [ˈʔɛŋlɪʃ]}} **{{lang|de|Anglo}} {{IPA|/ˈanɡloː/ [ˈʔaŋɡloː]}} **{{lang|de|Ganges}} {{IPA|/ˈɡanɡəs/ [ˈɡaŋəs]}} ~ {{IPA|/ˈɡanɡɛs/ [ˈɡaŋɡɛs]}}
===''Ich-Laut'' and ''ach-Laut''===<!-- the articles "Ich-Laut" and "Ach-Laut" redirect to this section heading--> '{{lang|de|Ich-Laut}}' is the [[voiceless palatal fricative]] {{IPAblink|ç}} (which is found in the word {{lang|de|ich}} {{IPA|[ʔɪç]}} 'I'), and '''{{lang|de|ach-Laut}}''' is the [[voiceless velar fricative]] {{IPAblink|x}} (which is found in the word {{lang|de|ach}} {{IPA|[ax]}} the interjection 'oh', 'alas'). Note that {{lang|de|Laut}} {{IPA|[laʊ̯t]}} is the German word for 'sound, [[phone (phonetics)|phone]]'. In German, these two sounds are [[allophone]]s occurring in [[complementary distribution]]. The allophone {{IPAblink|x}} occurs after back vowels and {{IPA|/a aː/}} (for instance in {{lang|de|Buch}} {{IPA|[buːx]}} 'book'), the allophone {{IPAblink|ç}} after front vowels (for instance in {{lang|de|mich}} {{IPA|[mɪç]}} 'me/myself') and consonants (for instance in {{lang|de|Furcht}} {{IPA|[fʊʁçt]}} 'fear', {{lang|de|manchmal}} {{IPA|[ˈmançmaːl]}} 'sometimes'). (This happens most regularly: if the {{angbr|r}} in {{lang|de|Furcht}} is pronounced as a consonant, {{lang|de|ch}} represents {{IPAblink|ç}}; however if, as often happens, it is vocalized as {{IPA|[ɐ]}}, resembling the vowel {{IPA|[a]}}, then {{angbr|ch}} may represent {{IPAblink|x}}, yielding {{IPA|[fʊɐ̯xt]}}.)
In [[loanword]]s, the pronunciation of potential [[Fricative consonant|fricatives]] in [[Onset (linguistics)|onsets]] of [[stressed syllable]]s varies: in the Northern varieties of standard German, it is {{IPAblink|ç}}, while in Southern varieties, it is {{IPAblink|k}}, and in Western varieties, it is {{IPAblink|ʃ}} (for instance in {{lang|de|China}}: {{IPA|[ˈçiːna]}} vs. {{IPA|[ˈkiːna]}} vs. {{IPA|[ˈʃiːna]}}).
The [[diminutive]] [[suffix]] {{lang|de|-chen}} is always pronounced with an {{lang|de|ich-Laut}} {{IPA|[-çən]}}.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Wiese|1996|p=217}}</ref> Usually, this ending triggers [[Germanic umlaut|umlaut]] (compare for instance {{lang|de|Hund}} {{IPA|[hʊnt]}} 'dog' to {{lang|de|Hündchen}} {{IPA|[ˈhʏntçn̩]}} 'little dog'), so theoretically, it could only occur after [[front vowel]]s. However, in some comparatively recent coinings, there is no longer an umlaut, for instance in the word {{lang|de|Frauchen}} {{IPA|[ˈfʀaʊ̯çən]}} (a diminutive of {{lang|de|Frau}} 'woman'), so that a back vowel is followed by a {{IPAblink|ç}}, even though normally it would be followed by a {{IPAblink|x}}, as in {{lang|de|rauchen}} {{IPA|[ˈʀaʊ̯xən]}} ('to smoke'). This exception to the allophonic distribution may be an effect of the morphemic boundary or an example of ''[[phonemic differentiation#Phonemic splits|phonemicization]]'', where erstwhile allophones undergo a split into separate [[phoneme]]s.
The allophonic distribution of {{IPAblink|ç}} after front vowels and {{IPAblink|x}} after other vowels is also found in other languages, such as [[Scots language|Scots]], in the pronunciation of ''light''. However, it is by no means inevitable: [[Dutch language|Dutch]], [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]], and many Southern German dialects retain {{IPAblink|x}} (which can be realized as {{IPAblink|χ}} instead) in all positions. It is thus reasonable to assume that [[Old High German]] ''ih'', the ancestor of modern {{lang|de|ich}}, was pronounced with {{IPAblink|x}} rather than {{IPAblink|ç}}. While it is impossible to know for certain whether [[Old English language|Old English]] words such as ''niht'' (modern ''night'') were pronounced with {{IPAblink|x}} or {{IPAblink|ç}}, {{IPAblink|ç}} is likely (see [[Old English phonology#Consonant allophones|Old English phonology]]).
Despite the phonetic history, the complementary distribution of {{IPAblink|ç}} and {{IPAblink|x}} in modern [[Standard German]] is better described as backing of {{IPAslink|ç}} after a [[back vowel]], rather than fronting of {{IPAslink|x}} after a [[front vowel]], because {{IPAblink|ç}} is used in [[Syllable#Onset|onsets]] ({{lang|de|Chemie}} {{IPA|[çeˈmiː]}} 'chemistry') and after consonants ({{lang|de|Molch}} {{IPA|[mɔlç]}} 'newt'), and is thus the [[underlying form]] of the phoneme.
According to Kohler,<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1977}} and {{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1990}}, as cited in {{Harvcoltxt|Wiese|1996|p=210}}</ref> the German {{lang|de|ach-Laut}} is further differentiated into two allophones, {{IPAblink|x}} and {{IPAblink|χ}}: {{IPAblink|x}} occurs after {{IPA|/uː, oː/}} (for instance in {{lang|de|Buch}} {{IPA|[buːx]}} 'book') and {{IPAblink|χ}} after {{IPA|/a, aː/}} (for instance in {{lang|de|Bach}} {{IPA|[baχ]}} 'brook'), while either {{IPAblink|x}} or {{IPAblink|χ}} may occur after {{IPA|/ʊ, ɔ, aʊ̯/}}, with {{IPAblink|χ}} predominating.
===Fortis–lenis pairs=== Various German consonants occur in pairs at the same [[place of articulation]] and in the same [[manner of articulation]], namely the pairs {{IPA|/p–b/}}, {{IPA|/t–d/}}, {{IPA|/k–ɡ/}}, {{IPA|/s–z/}}, {{IPA|/ʃ–ʒ/}}. These pairs are often called [[Fortis and lenis|fortis–lenis]] pairs, since describing them as voiced–voiceless pairs is inadequate. With certain qualifications, {{IPA|/t͡ʃ–d͡ʒ/}}, {{IPA|/f–v/}} and {{IPA|/θ–ð/}} are also considered fortis–lenis pairs.
Fortis-lenis distinction for {{IPA|/ʔ, m, n, ŋ, l, r, h/}} is unimportant.<ref name=folemangold>{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=56}}</ref>
The fortis stops {{IPA|/p, t, k/}} are [[Aspirated consonant|aspirated]] in many varieties. The aspiration is strongest in the onset of a [[stressed syllable]] (such as {{lang|de|Taler}} {{IPA|[ˈtʰaːlɐ]}} 'thaler'), weaker in the [[Onset (linguistics)|onset]] of an [[unstressed syllable]] (such as {{lang|de|Vater}} {{IPA|[ˈfaːtʰɐ]}} 'father'), and weakest in the [[syllable coda]] (such as in {{lang|de|Saat}} {{IPA|[zaːtʰ]}} 'seed'). All fortis consonants, i.e. {{IPA|/p, t, k, f, θ, s, ʃ, ç, x, p͡f, t͡s, t͡ʃ/}}<ref name=folemangold/> are fully voiceless.<ref name=vlessfortis>{{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005|p=55}}</ref>
The lenis consonants {{IPA|/b, d, ɡ, v, ð, z, ʒ, j, r, d͡ʒ/}}<ref name=folemangold/> range from being weakly voiced to almost voiceless {{IPA|[b̥, d̥, ɡ̊, v̥, ð̥, z̥, ʒ̊, j̥, r̥, d͜ʒ̊]}} after voiceless consonants:<ref name=vlessfortis/> {{lang|de|Kas'''b'''ah}} {{IPA|[ˈkasb̥a]}} ('kasbah)', {{lang|de|ab'''d'''anken}} {{IPA|[ˈʔapd̥aŋkn̩]}} ('to resign'), {{lang|de|rot'''g'''elb}} {{IPA|[ˈʁoːtɡ̊ɛlp]}} ('red-yellow'), {{lang|de|Ab'''w'''urf}} {{IPA|[ˈʔapv̥ʊʁf]}} ('dropping'), {{lang|de|Ab'''s'''icht}} {{IPA|[ˈʔapz̥ɪçt]}} ('intention'), {{lang|de|Holz'''j'''alousie}} {{IPA|[ˈhɔlt͜sʒ̊aluziː]}} ('wooden jalousie'), {{lang|de|weg'''j'''agen}} {{IPA|[ˈvɛkj̥aːɡn̩]}} ('to chase away'), {{lang|de|t'''r'''opfen}} {{IPA|[ˈtʁ̥ɔp͡fn̩]}} ('to drop'), {{lang|de|Obst'''j'''uice}} {{IPA|[ˈʔoːpstd͜ʒ̊uːs]}} ('fruit juice'). {{Harvcoltxt|Mangold|2005}} states that they are "to a large extent voiced" {{IPA|[b, d, g, v, ð, z, ʒ, j, r, d͡ʒ]}} in all other environments,<ref name=folemangold/> but some studies have found the stops {{IPA|/b, d, ɡ/}} to be voiceless word/utterance-initially in most dialects (while still contrasting with {{IPA|/p, t, k/}} due to the aspiration of the latter).<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Jessen|Ringen|2002|p=190}}</ref>
{{IPA|/b, d, ɡ, z, ʒ/}} are [[Voicelessness|voiceless]] in most southern varieties of German. For clarity, they are often transcribed as {{IPA|[b̥, d̥, ɡ̊, z̥, ʒ̊]}}.
The nature of the phonetic difference between the voiceless lenis consonants and the similarly voiceless fortis consonants is controversial. It is generally described as a difference in articulatory force, and occasionally as a difference in articulatory length; for the most part, it is assumed that one of these characteristics implies the other.
In various central and southern varieties, the opposition between fortis and lenis is neutralized in the [[syllable onset]]; sometimes just in the onset of stressed syllables, sometimes in all cases.
The pair {{IPA|/f-v/}} is not considered a fortis–lenis pair, but a simple voiceless–voiced pair, as {{IPAslink|v}} remains [[voiced]] in all varieties, including the Southern varieties that [[Devoiced|devoice]] the lenes (with however some exceptions).<ref>{{clarify span|text=[v] written {{lang|de|v}}|explain=Mixing orthography with phonology; what's the phonological analysis here?|date=April 2013}} can devoice in nearly every place once the word has become common; {{lang|de|w}} is devoiced in {{lang|de|Möwe, Löwe}}. On the other hand, the keeping to the variety is so standard that {{lang|de|doof}} {{IPA|/do:f/}} induced the writing "(der) doofe" even though the standard pronunciation of the latter word is {{IPA|/ˈdoːvə/}}</ref> Generally, the southern {{IPAslink|v}} is realized as the voiced [[approximant]] {{IPAblink|ʋ}}. However, there are southern varieties which differentiate between a fortis {{IPAslink|f}} (such as in {{lang|de|sträflich}} {{IPA|[ˈʃtrɛːflɪç]}} 'culpable' from [[Middle High German]] stræflich) and a lenis {{IPAslink|f}} ({{IPA|[v̥]}}, such as in {{lang|de|höflich}} {{IPA|[ˈhøːv̥lɪç]}} 'polite' from Middle High German hovelîch); this is analogous to the opposition of fortis {{IPAslink|s}} ({{IPAblink|s}}) and lenis {{IPA|[z̥]}}.
====Coda devoicing==== In varieties from Northern Germany, lenis stops in the [[syllable coda]] are realized as fortis stops. This does not happen in varieties from Southern Germany, Austria or Switzerland.{{refn|See {{harvtxt|Ammonn|Bickel|Ebner|Esterhammer|2004|page=LVII}}.}}
Since the lenis stops {{IPA|/b, d, ɡ/}} are unvoiced or at most variably voiced (as stated above), this cannot be called devoicing in the strict sense of the word because it does not involve the loss of [[Voice (phonetics)|phonetic voice]].<ref name="uiowa.edu">{{Harvcoltxt|Beckman|Jessen|Ringen|2009|p=233}}</ref> More accurately, it can be called coda [[fortition]] or a [[Phoneme#Neutralization, archiphoneme, and underspecification|neutralization]] of fortis and lenis sounds in the coda. Fricatives are truly and contrastively voiced in Northern Germany.{{refn|In Southern Germany, Austria or Switzerland there is no phonetic voice in fricatives either, see {{harvtxt|Ammonn|Bickel|Ebner|Esterhammer|2004|page=LVII}}.}} Therefore, the fricatives undergo [[Final-obstruent devoicing|coda devoicing]] in the strict sense of the word.<ref name="uiowa.edu"/> It is disputed whether coda devoicing is due to a constraint which specifically operates on syllable codas or whether it arises from constraints which "protect voicing in privileged positions."<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Beckman|Jessen|Ringen|2009|pp=264–265}}</ref>
As against standard pronunciation rules, in western varieties including those of the [[Rhineland]], coda fortis–lenis neutralization results in ''voicing'' rather than ''devoicing'' if the following word begins with a vowel. For example, {{lang|de|mit uns}} becomes {{IPA|[mɪ'''d'''‿ʊns]}} and {{lang|de|darf ich}} becomes {{IPA|[daʁ'''v'''‿ɪʃ]}}. The same [[sandhi]] phenomenon exists also as a general rule in the [[Luxembourgish]] language.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://infolux.uni.lu/phonetik/lautstruktur-des-luxemburgischen/wortuebergreifende-phaenomene/ |title=Lautstruktur des Luxemburgischen - Wortübergreifende Phänomene |accessdate=2013-05-15}}</ref>
==Stress== [[lexical stress|Stress]] in German usually falls on the first syllable, with the following exceptions: * Many [[loanword]]s, especially proper names, keep their original stress. E.g. {{lang|de|Obama}} {{IPA|/oˈbaː.ma/}} * Nouns formed with Latinate suffixes, such as {{lang|de|-ant, -anz, -enz, -ion, -ismus, -ist, -ment, -tät}}: {{lang|de|Idealismus}} {{IPA|/ide.aˈlɪsmʊs/}} ('idealism'), {{lang|de|Konsonant}} {{IPA|/kɔnzoˈnant/}} ('consonant'), {{lang|de|Tourist}} {{IPA|/tuˈʁɪst/}} ('tourist') * Verbs formed with the French-derived suffix ''-ieren'', e.g. {{lang|de|studieren}} {{IPA|/ʃtuˈdiːʁən/}} ('to study'). This is often pronounced {{IPA|/iːɐ̯n/}} in casual speech. * Compound adverbs with {{lang|de|her}}, {{lang|de|hin}}, {{lang|de|da}}, or {{lang|de|wo}} as they are stressed on the first syllable of the second element, e.g. {{lang|de|dagegen}} {{IPA|/daˈɡeːɡən/}} ('on the other hand'), {{lang|de|woher}} {{IPA|/voˈheːɐ̯/}} ('from where') In addition, German uses different stress for separable [[prefix]]es and inseparable prefixes in verbs and words derived from such verbs: * Words beginning with {{lang|de|be-}}, {{lang|de|ge-}}, {{lang|de|er-}}, {{lang|de|ver-}}, {{lang|de|zer-}}, {{lang|de|ent-}}, {{lang|de|emp-}} and a few other inseparable prefixes are stressed on the root. * Words beginning with the separable prefixes {{lang|de|ab-}}, {{lang|de|auf-}}, {{lang|de|ein-}}, {{lang|de|vor-}}, and most [[prepositional adverb]]s are stressed on the prefix. * Some prefixes, notably {{lang|de|über-}}, {{lang|de|unter-}}, {{lang|de|um-}}, and {{lang|de|durch-}}, can function as separable or inseparable prefixes and are stressed or not accordingly. * A few homographs with such prefixes exist. They are not perfect homophones. Consider the word {{lang|de|umschreiben}}. As {{lang|de|ˈum•schreiben}} (separable prefix), it means 'to rewrite' and is pronounced {{IPA|[ˈʔʊmʃʀaɪ̯bən]}}, with stress on the first syllable. Its associated noun, {{lang|de|die ˈUmschreibung}} is also stressed on the first syllable - {{IPA|[ˈʔʊmʃʀaɪ̯bʊŋ]}}. On the other hand, {{lang|de|umˈschreiben}} (inseparable prefix) is pronounced {{IPA|[ʔʊmˈʃʀaɪ̯bən]}}, with stress on the second syllable. This word means 'to paraphrase', and its associated noun, {{lang|de|die Umˈschreibung}} is also stressed on the second syllable - {{IPA|[ʔʊmˈʃʀaɪ̯bʊŋ]}}. Another example is the word {{lang|de|umˈfahren}}; with stress on the root ({{IPA|[ʔʊmˈfaːʀən]}}) it means 'to drive around (an obstacle in the street)', and with stress on the prefix ({{IPA|[ˈʔʊmfaːʀən]}}) it means 'to run down/over' or 'to knock down'.
==Acquisition==
===General=== Like all infants, German infants go through a [[babbling]] stage in the early phases of phonological acquisition, during which they produce the sounds they will later use in their first words.<ref name="Meibauer 261">{{Harvcoltxt|Meibauer|Demske|Geilfuß-Wolfgang|Pafel|2007|p=261}}</ref> [[Phoneme]] inventories begin with [[Stop consonant|stops]], [[nasal consonant|nasals]], and [[vowel]]s; (contrasting) [[short vowel]]s and [[Liquid consonant|liquids]] appear next, followed by [[Fricative consonant|fricatives]] and [[Affricate consonant|affricates]], and finally all other [[German phonology#Consonants|consonants]] and [[consonant cluster]]s.<ref name="Meibauer 263">{{Harvcoltxt|Meibauer|Demske|Geilfuß-Wolfgang|Pafel|2007|p=263}}</ref> Children begin to produce protowords near the end of their first year. These words do not approximate adult forms, yet have a specific and consistent meaning.<ref name="Meibauer 261"/> Early word productions are phonetically simple and usually follow the [[syllable]] structure CV or CVC, although this generalization has been challenged.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Grijzenhout|Joppen|1998|p=1}}</ref> The first [[German phonology#Vowels|vowels]] produced are {{IPA|/ə/}}, {{IPA|/a/}}, and {{IPA|/aː/}}, followed by {{IPA|/e/}}, {{IPA|/i/}}, and {{IPA|/ɛ/}}, with [[rounded vowel]]s emerging last.<ref name="Meibauer 263"/> German children often use phonological processes to simplify their early word production.<ref name="Meibauer 263"/> For example, they may delete an unstressed syllable ({{lang|de|Schokolade}} 'chocolate' pronounced {{IPA|[ˈlaːdə]}}),<ref name="Meibauer 263"/> or replace a fricative with a corresponding stop ({{lang|de|Dach}} {{IPA|[dax]}} 'roof' pronounced {{IPA|[dak]}}).<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Meibauer|Demske|Geilfuß-Wolfgang|Pafel|2007|p=264}}</ref> One case study found that a 17-month-old child acquiring German replaced the [[voiceless velar fricative]] {{IPA|[x]}} with the nearest available [[continuant]] {{IPA|[h]}}, or deleted it altogether ({{lang|de|Buch}} {{IPA|[buːx]}} 'book' pronounced {{IPA|[buh]}} or {{IPA|[buː]}}).<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Grijzenhout|Joppen|1998|p=12}}</ref>
===Vowel space development=== In 2009, Lintfert examined the development of [[vowel space]] of German speakers in their first three years of life. During the [[babbling]] stage, vowel distribution has no clear pattern. However, [[Stress (linguistics)|stressed]] and [[unstressed vowel]]s already show different distributions in the vowel space. Once word production begins, [[Stress (linguistics)|stressed vowels]] expand in the [[vowel space]], while the [[Vowel height|F1]]-[[Vowel backness|F2]] vowel space of unstressed vowels becomes more centralized. The majority of infants are then capable of stable production of F1.<ref name="Lintfert 159">{{Harvcoltxt|Lintfert|2010|p=159}}</ref> It should be noted that the variability of [[Formant|formant frequencies]] among individuals decreases with age.<ref name="Lintfert 138">{{Harvcoltxt|Lintfert|2010|p=138}}</ref> After 24 months, infants expand their vowel space individually at different rates. However, if the parents' utterances possess a well-defined vowel space, their children produce clearly distinguished vowel classes earlier.<ref name="Lintfert 160">{{Harvcoltxt|Lintfert|2010|p=160}}</ref> By about three years old, children command the production of all vowels, and they attempt to produce the four [[cardinal vowel]]s, {{IPA|/y/}}, {{IPA|/i/}}, {{IPA|/u/}} and {{IPA|/a/}}, at the extreme limits of the F1-F2 vowel space (i.e., the height and backness of the vowels are made extreme by the infants).<ref name="Lintfert 138"/>
===Grammatical words=== Generally, [[Closed class|closed-class]] grammatical words (e.g. articles and prepositions) are absent from children's speech when they first begin to combine words.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Höhle|Weissenborn|2003|p=122}}</ref> However, children as young as 18 months old show knowledge of these closed-class words when they prefer stories with them, compared to passages with them omitted. Therefore, the absence of these grammatical words cannot be due to perceptual problems.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Höhle|Weissenborn|2003|p=123}}</ref> Researchers tested children's comprehension of four grammatical words: {{lang|de|bis}} {{IPA|[bɪs}}] ('up to'), {{lang|de|von}} {{IPA|[fɔn]}} ('from'), {{lang|de|das}} {{IPA|[das]}} ('the' neuter singular), and {{lang|de|sein}} {{IPA|[zaɪ̯n]}} ('his'). After first being familiarized with the words, eight-month-old children looked longer in the direction of a speaker playing a text passage that contained these previously heard words.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Höhle|Weissenborn|2003|p=125}}</ref> However, this ability is absent in six-month-olds.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Höhle|Weissenborn|2003|p=126}}</ref>
===Nasals=== The acquisition of nasals in German differs from that of [[Dutch language|Dutch]], a phonologically closely related language.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Altvater-Mackensen|Fikkert|2007|p=14}}</ref> German children produce proportionately more nasals in [[Syllable#Onset|onset position]] (sounds before a vowel in a syllable) than Dutch children do.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Altvater-Mackensen|Fikkert|2007|p=16}}</ref> German children, once they reached 16 months, also produced significantly more nasals in syllables containing [[schwa]]s, when compared with Dutch-speaking children.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Altvater-Mackensen|Fikkert|2007|p=19}}</ref> This may reflect differences in the languages the children are being exposed to, although the researchers claim that the development of nasals likely cannot be seen apart from the more general phonological system the child is developing.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Altvater-Mackensen|Fikkert|2007|p=23}}</ref>
===Phonotactic constraints and reading=== A 2006 study examined the acquisition of German in [[Speech-Language Pathology|phonologically delayed]] children (specifically, issues with fronting of [[Velar consonant|velars]] and stopping of fricatives) and whether they applied [[Optimality Theory|phonotactic constraints]] to word-initial [[consonant cluster]]s containing these modified consonants.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Ott|van de Vijner|Höhle|2006|p=323}}</ref> In many cases, the subjects (mean age = 5;1) avoided making [[Phonotactics|phonotactic]] violations, opting instead for other consonants or clusters in their speech. This suggests that phonotactic constraints do apply to the speech of German children with phonological delay, at least in the case of word-initial consonant clusters.<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Ott|van de Vijner|Höhle|2006|p=331}}</ref> Additional research<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Goswami|Ziegler|Richardson|2005|p=362}}</ref> has also shown that spelling consistencies seen in German raise children's [[phonemic awareness]] as they acquire reading skills.
==Sound changes==
===Sound changes and mergers=== A [[Merger (phonology)|merger]] found mostly in Northern accents of German is that of {{IPA|/ɛː/}} (spelled {{angbr|ä, äh}}) with {{IPA|/eː/}} (spelled {{angbr|e}}, {{angbr|ee}}, or {{angbr|eh}}). Some speakers merge the two everywhere, some distinguish them everywhere, others keep {{IPA|/ɛː/}} distinct only in [[conditional mood|conditional]] forms of [[strong inflection|strong]] [[verb]]s (for example {{lang|de|ich gäbe}} {{IPA|[ˈɡɛːbə]}} 'I would give' vs. {{lang|de|ich gebe}} {{IPA|[ˈɡeːbə]}} 'I give' are distinguished, but {{lang|de|Bären}} {{IPA|[ˈbeːʁən]}} 'bears' vs. {{lang|de|Beeren}} {{IPA|[ˈbeːʁən]}} 'berries' are not. Standard pronunciation of {{lang|de|Bären}} is {{IPA|[ˈbɛːʁən]}}).
Another common [[Merger (phonology)|merger]] is that of {{IPA|/ɡ/}} at the end of a syllable with {{IPA|[ç]}} or {{IPA|[x]}}, for instance {{lang|de|Krieg}} {{IPA|[kʁ̥iː'''ç''']}} ('war'), but {{lang|de|Kriege}} {{IPA|[ˈkʁ̥iː'''ɡ'''ə]}} ('wars'); {{lang|de|er lag}} {{IPA|[laː'''x''']}} ('he lay'), but {{lang|de|wir lagen}} {{IPA|[ˈlaː'''ɡ'''ən]}} ('we lay'). This pronunciation is frequent all over central and northern Germany. It is characteristic of regional languages and dialects, particularly [[Low German]] in the North, where {{angbr|g}} represents a [[Fricative consonant|fricative]], becoming [[Voicelessness|voiceless]] in the [[syllable coda]], as is common in German ([[final-obstruent devoicing]]). However common it is, this pronunciation is considered sub-standard. Only in one case, in the grammatical ending {{lang|de|-ig}} (which corresponds to English ''-y''), the fricative pronunciation of final {{angbr|g}} is prescribed by the [[Theodor Siebs|Siebs]] standard, for instance {{lang|de|wichtig}} {{IPA|[ˈvɪçtɪç]}} ('important'). The merger occurs neither in [[Austro-Bavarian]] and [[Alemannic German]] nor in the corresponding varieties of [[Standard German]], and therefore in these regions {{lang|de|-ig}} is pronounced {{IPA|[ɪɡ̊]}}.
Many speakers do not distinguish the [[affricate]] {{IPA|/p͡f/}} from the simple [[fricative]] {{IPA|/f/}} in the beginning of a word, in which case the verb {{lang|de|(er) fährt}} ('[he] travels') and the noun {{lang|de|Pferd}} ('horse') are both pronounced {{IPA|[fɛɐ̯t]}}. This most commonly occurs in northern and western Germany, where the local dialects did not originally have the sound {{IPA|/p͡f/}}. Some speakers also have peculiar pronunciation for {{IPA|/p͡f/}} in the middle or end of a word, replacing the {{IPA|[f]}} in {{IPA|/p͡f/}} with a [[voiceless bilabial fricative]], i.e. a consonant produced by pressing air flow through the tensed lips. Thereby {{lang|de|Tropfen}} ('drop') becomes {{IPA|[ˈtʁ̥ɔp͡ɸn̩]}}, rather than {{IPA|[ˈtʁ̥ɔp͡fn̩]}}.
Many speakers who have a vocalization of {{IPA|/r/}} after {{IPA|/a/}} merge this combination with long {{IPA|/aː/}} (i.e. {{IPA|/ar/}} > {{IPA|*[aɐ]}} or {{IPA|*[ɑɐ]}} > {{IPA|[aː]}} or {{IPA|[ɑː]}}). Hereby, {{lang|de|Schaf}} ('sheep') and {{lang|de|scharf}} ('sharp') can both be pronounced {{IPA|[ʃaːf]}} or {{IPA|[ʃɑːf]}}. This merger does not occur where {{IPA|/a/}} is a front vowel while {{IPA|/aː/}} is realised as a back vowel. Here the words are kept distinct as {{IPA|[ʃɑːf]}} ('sheep') and {{IPA|[ʃaːf]}} ('sharp'). <br> In umlaut forms, the difference usually reoccurs: {{lang|de|Schäfer}} {{IPA|[ˈʃɛːfɐ]}} or {{IPA|{{IPA|[ˈʃeːfɐ]}}}} vs. {{lang|de|schärfer}} {{IPA|[ˈʃɛɐ̯fɐ]}}. Speakers with this merger also often use {{IPA|[aːç]}} (instead of formally normal {{IPA|/aːx/}}) where it stems from original {{IPA|/arç/}}. The word {{lang|de|Archen}} ('arks') is thus pronounced {{IPA|[ˈʔaːçn̩]}}, which makes a minimal pair with {{lang|de|[[Aachen]]}} {{IPA|[ʔaːxn̩]}}, making the difference between {{IPA|[ç]}} and {{IPA|[x]}} [[phonem]]ic, rather than just [[allophone|allophonic]], for these speakers.
In the standard pronunciation, the vowel qualities {{IPA|/i/}}, {{IPA|/ɪ/}}, {{IPA|/e/}}, {{IPA|/ɛ/}}, as well as {{IPA|/u/}}, {{IPA|/ʊ/}}, {{IPA|/o/}}, {{IPA|/ɔ/}}, are all still distinguished even in unstressed syllables. In this latter case, however, many simplify the system in various degrees. For some speakers, this may go so far as to merge all four into one, whence misspellings by schoolchildren such as {{lang|de|Bräut'''e'''gam}} (instead of {{lang|de|Bräut'''i'''gam}}) or {{lang|de|Port'''o'''gal}} (instead of ''Port'''u'''gal'').
In everyday speech, more [[Merger (phonology)|mergers]] occur, some of which are universal and some of which are typical for certain regions or dialect backgrounds. Overall, there is a strong tendency of reduction and contraction. For example, long vowels may be shortened, consonant clusters may be simplified, word-final {{IPA|[ə]}} may be dropped in some cases, and the suffix {{lang|de|-en}} may be contracted with preceding consonants, e.g. {{IPA|[ham]}} for {{lang|de|haben}} {{IPA|[ˈhaːbən]}} ('to have').
If the clusters {{IPA|[mp]}}, {{IPA|[lt]}}, {{IPA|[nt]}}, or {{IPA|[ŋk]}} are followed by another consonant, the stops {{IPA|/p/}}, {{IPA|/t/}} and {{IPA|/k/}} usually lose their phonemic status. Thus while the standard pronunciation distinguishes {{lang|de|ganz}} {{IPA|[ɡant͡s]}} ('whole') from {{lang|de|Gans}} {{IPA|[ɡans]}} ('goose'), as well as {{lang|de|er sinkt}} {{IPA|[zɪŋkt]}} from {{lang|de|er singt}} {{IPA|[zɪŋt]}}, the two pairs are homophones for most speakers. The commonest practice is to drop the stop (thus {{IPA|[ɡans]}}, {{IPA|[zɪŋt]}} for both words), but some speakers insert the stop where it is not etymological ({{IPA|[ɡants]}}, {{IPA|[zɪŋkt]}} for both words), or they alternate between the two ways. Only a few speakers retain a phonemic distinction.
===Middle High German=== The [[Middle High German]] vowels {{IPA|[ei̯]}} and {{IPA|[iː]}} developed into the modern [[Standard German]] diphthong {{IPA|[aɪ̯]}}, whereas {{IPA|[ou̯]}} and {{IPA|[uː]}} developed into {{IPA|[aʊ̯]}}. For example, Middle High German {{lang|gmh|heiz}} {{IPA|/hei̯s/}} and {{lang|gmh|wîz}} {{IPA|/wiːs/}} ('hot' and 'white') became Standard German {{lang|de|heiß}} {{IPA|/haɪ̯s/}} and {{lang|de|weiß}} {{IPA|/vaɪ̯s/}}. In some dialects, the Middle High German vowels have not changed, e.g. [[Swiss German]] {{lang|de|heiss}} {{IPA|/hei̯s/}} and {{lang|de|wiiss}} {{IPA|/viːs/}}, while in other dialects or languages, the vowels have changed but the distinction is kept, e.g. [[Bavarian language|Bavarian]] {{lang|bar|hoaß}} {{IPA|/hɔɐ̯s/}} and {{lang|bar|weiß}} {{IPA|/vaɪ̯s/}}, [[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian]] {{lang|ksh|heeß}} {{IPA|/heːs/}} and {{lang|ksh|wieß}} {{IPA|/viːs/}}, [[Yiddish]] {{lang|yi|הײס}} ''{{transl|yi|heys}}'' {{IPA|/hɛɪ̯s/}} and {{lang|yi|װײַס}} ''{{transl|yi|vays}}'' {{IPA|/vaɪ̯s/}}.
The Middle High German [[diphthong]]s {{IPA|[iə̯]}}, {{IPA|[uə̯]}} and {{IPA|[yə̯]}} became the modern [[Standard German]] long vowels {{IPA|[iː]}}, {{IPA|[uː]}} and {{IPA|[yː]}} after the Middle High German long vowels changed to diphthongs. Most [[Upper German]] dialects retain the diphthongs. A remnant of their former diphthong character is shown when {{IPA|[iː]}} continues to be written {{lang|de|ie}} in German (as in {{lang|de|Liebe}} 'love').
==Loanwords==
German incorporates a significant number of [[loanword]]s from other languages. Loanwords are often adapted to German phonology but to varying degrees, depending on the speaker and the commonness of the word. {{IPA|/ʒ/}} and {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}} do not occur in native German words but are common in a number of French and English loan words. Many speakers replace them with {{IPA|/ʃ/}} and {{IPA|/t͡ʃ/}} respectively (especially in Southern Germany, Austria and Switzerland), so that {{lang|de|Dschungel}} (from English ''jungle'') can be pronounced {{IPA|[ˈd͡ʒʊŋl̩]}} or {{IPA|[ˈt͡ʃʊŋl̩]}}. Some speakers in Northern and Western Germany merge {{IPA|/ʒ/}} with {{IPA|/d͡ʒ/}}, so that {{lang|de|Journalist}} (phonemically {{IPA|/d͡ʒʊʁnaˈlɪst ~ ʒʊʁnaˈlɪst/}}) can be pronounced {{IPA|[ʒʊɐ̯naˈlɪst]}}, {{IPA|[d͡ʒʊɐ̯naˈlɪst]}} or {{IPA|[ʃʊɐ̯naˈlɪst]}}. The realization of {{IPA|/ʒ/}} as {{IPA|[t͡ʃ]}}, however, is uncommon.<ref>http://prowiki.ids-mannheim.de/bin/view/AADG/ZhimAnlaut</ref>
===Loanwords from English=== Many English words are used in German, especially in technology and pop culture. Some speakers pronounce them similarly to their native pronunciation, but many speakers change non-native phonemes to similar German phonemes (even if they pronounce them in a rather English manner in an English-language setting): * English {{IPA|/θ, ð/}} are usually pronounced as in RP or General American; some speakers replace them with {{IPA|/s/}} and {{IPA|/z/}} respectively ([[th-alveolarization]]) e.g. {{lang|de|Thriller}} {{IPA|[ˈθʁɪlɐ ~ ˈsʁɪlɐ]}}. * English {{IPA|/ɹ/}} can be pronounced the same as in English, i.e. {{IPAblink|ɹ}}, or as the corresponding native German {{IPA|/r/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Rock}} {{IPA|[ʀɔk]}} or {{IPA|[rɔk]}}. German and Austrian speakers tend to be [[Rhotic_consonant#Other_Germanic_languages|variably rhotic]]. * English {{IPA|/w/}} is often replaced with German {{IPA|/v/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Whiskey}} {{IPA|[ˈvɪskiː]}}. * word-initial {{IPA|/s/}} is often retained (especially in the South, where word-initial {{IPA|/s/}} is common),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prowiki.ids-mannheim.de/bin/view/AADG/SimAnlaut|title=SimAnlaut < AADG < TWiki|author=|date=|website=prowiki.ids-mannheim.de|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> but many speakers replace it with {{IPA|/z/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Sound}} {{IPA|[zaʊ̯nt]}}. * word-initial {{IPA|/st/}} and {{IPA|/sp/}} are usually retained, but some speakers (especially in South Western Germany and Western Austria) replace them with {{IPA|/ʃt/}} and {{IPA|/ʃp/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Steak}} {{IPA|[ʃteɪk]}} or {{IPA|[ʃteːk]}}, {{lang|de|Spray}} {{IPA|[ʃpʁeɪ]}} or {{IPA|[ʃpʁeː]}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prowiki.ids-mannheim.de/bin/view/AADG/SteakSprayStSp|title=SteakSprayStSp < AADG < TWiki|author=|date=|website=prowiki.ids-mannheim.de|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> * English {{IPA|/t͡ʃ/}} is usually retained, but in Northern and Western Germany, as well as Luxembourg it is often replaced with {{IPA|/ʃ/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Chips}} {{IPA|[ʃɪps]}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prowiki.ids-mannheim.de/bin/view/AADG/ChipsCh|title=ChipsCh < AADG < TWiki|author=|date=|website=prowiki.ids-mannheim.de|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> * In Northern Standard German, [[final-obstruent devoicing]] is applied to English loan words just as to other words e.g. {{lang|de|Airbag}} {{IPA|[ˈɛːɐ̯bɛk]}}, {{lang|de|Lord}} {{IPA|[lɔʁt]}} or {{IPA|[lɔɐ̯t]}}, {{lang|de|Backstage}} {{IPA|[ˈbɛksteːt͡ʃ]}}. However, in Southern Standard German, in Swiss Standard German and Austrian Standard German, final-obstruent devoicing does not occur and so speakers are more likely to retain the original pronunciation of word-final lenes (although realizing them as fortes may occur because of confusing English spelling with pronunciation). * English {{IPA|/eɪ/}} and {{IPA|/oʊ/}} are often replaced with {{IPA|/eː/}} and {{IPA|/oː/}} respectively e.g. {{lang|de|Homepage}} {{IPA|[ˈhoːmpeːt͡ʃ]}}. * English {{IPA|/æ/}} and {{IPA|/ɛ/}} are pronounced the same, as German {{IPA|/ɛ/}} ([[met–mat merger]]) e.g. {{lang|de|Backup}} {{IPA|[ˈbɛkap]}}. * English {{IPA|/ɒ/}} and {{IPA|/ɔː/}} are pronounced the same, as German {{IPA|/ɔ/}} ([[cot–caught merger]]) e.g. {{lang|de|Box}} {{IPA|[bɔks]}}. * English {{IPA|/ʌ/}} is usually pronounced as German {{IPA|/a/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Cutter}} {{IPA|[ˈkatɐ]}}. * English {{IPA|/ɜːr/}} is usually pronounced as German {{IPA|/œʁ/}} e.g. {{lang|de|Shirt}} {{IPA|[ʃœʁt]}} or {{IPA|[ʃœɐ̯t]}}. * English {{IPA|/i/}} is pronounced as {{IPA|/iː/}} ([[happy-tensing]]) e.g. {{lang|de|Whisk(e)y}} {{IPA|[ˈvɪskiː]}}.
==Sample== The sample text is a reading of the first sentence of "[[The North Wind and the Sun]]". The phonemic transcription treats every instance of {{IPA|[ɐ]}} and {{IPA|[ɐ̯]}} as {{IPA|/ər/}} and {{IPA|/r/}}, respectively. The phonetic transcription is a fairly narrow transcription of the educated northern accent. The speaker transcribed in the narrow transcription is 62 years old, and he is reading in a colloquial style.<ref name="Kohler86"/> Aspiration, glottal stops and devoicing of the lenes after fortes are not transcribed.
Note that the audio file contains the whole fable, and that it was recorded by a much younger speaker.
===Phonemic transcription=== {{IPA|/aɪ̯nst ˈʃtrɪtən zɪç ˈnɔrtvɪnt ʊnt ˈzɔnə {{!}} veːr fɔn iːnən ˈbaɪ̯dən voːl deːr ˈʃtɛrkərə vɛːrə {{!}} als aɪ̯n ˈvandərər {{!}} deːr ɪn aɪ̯nən ˈvarmən ˈmantəl ɡəˌhʏlt var {{!}} dɛs ˈveːɡəs daˈheːrkaːm/}}<ref>In Swiss Standard German and Austrian Standard German, {{lang|de|Nordwind}} and {{lang|de|und}} are pronounced {{IPA|/ˈnɔrdʋɪnd/}} and {{IPA|/ʊnd/}}, respectively.</ref>
{{Listen|filename=NordwindSonne.wav|title=The North Wind and the Sun|description=Traditional fable|format=[[wav]]}}
===Phonetic transcription=== {{IPA|[aɪ̯ns ˈʃtʁɪtn̩ zɪç ˈnɔɐ̯tvɪnt ʊn ˈzɔnə {{!}} veːɐ̯ fən iːm ˈbaɪ̯dn̩ voːl dɐ ˈʃtɛɐ̯kəʁə veːʁə {{!}} als aɪ̯n ˈvandəʁɐ {{!}} dɛɐ̯ ɪn aɪ̯n ˈvaɐ̯m ˈmantl̩ ɡəˌhʏlt vaɐ̯ {{!}} dəs ˈveːɡəs daˈheːɐ̯kaːm]}}<ref>Source: {{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1999|p=88}}. Note that in the original transcription the vowel length is not indicated, apart from where it is phonemic - that is, for the pairs {{IPA|/a/}} - {{IPA|/aː/}} and {{IPA|/ɛ/}} - {{IPA|/ɛː/}}.</ref>
===Orthographic version=== {{lang|de|Einst stritten sich Nordwind und Sonne, wer von ihnen beiden wohl der Stärkere wäre, als ein Wanderer, der in einen warmen Mantel gehüllt war, des Weges daherkam.}}<ref>{{Harvcoltxt|Kohler|1999|p=89}}</ref>

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Types of restaurants]] to [[Category:Restaurants by type]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Italic title}} [[File:Private wine licence sign.jpg|thumb|Information sign on a bicycle to a 'Strausse', a private wine licence in Boetzingen, Germany]] A '''''Strausse''''' or '''''Strausswirtschaft''''' (also '''''Strauße''''' or '''''Straußwirtschaft''''') is a type of wine tavern in [[winegrowing]] areas of [[German language|German]]-speaking countries that is only open during certain times of the year. Typically it is a pub run by winegrowers and winemakers themselves, in which they sell their own wine directly to the public. The food served needs to be simple, regional cold dishes. Other expressions like ''Besenwirtschaft'' and ''Besenschänke'' ("broom pub"), ''Rädlewirtschaft'' ("cyclists' pub") as well as ''Hecken-'' or ''Häckerwirtschaft'' are also common.
==Characterization==
A ''Strausswirtschaft'' is essentially understood to be a winemaker serving his own wine on his own premises. These seasonal inns are not subject to normal business laws and are thus not obliged to have a licence or to pay extra taxes. They must, however, fulfil certain conditions instead. These conditions vary from [[States of Germany|state]] to state but they are in general agreement on certain essential points (see "Legal aspects" below).
The kinds of locations in which a ''Strausswirtschaft'' can be found can vary considerably. Besides ones funished like ordinary pubs there are also simple barns where benches and tables have been temporarily set up to accommodate guests. In earlier decades some winegrowers even cleared their flats or the stables to run such a tavern. In [[Austria]] this kind of pub is called a ''[[Buschenschank]]'' or ''[[Heuriger]]''. The name is derived from a bar or post to which a so-called ''Föhrenbusch'' or a ''Reisigbesen'' (a kind of besom or broom) was attached. This helps to explain another expression associated with the Strausswirtschaft: ''Ausg'steckt is{{'}}'' ("It is attached"). By attaching the bar outside, the pub owner was informing the tax collector about the pub's tax liability. The ''Buschenschank'' and the expression ''Ausg'steckt is{{'}}'' can be traced back to a regulation by [[Maria Theresa of Austria|Empress Maria Theresia]].
==Origins==
The enactment "''[[Capitulare de villis]] vel curtis imperii''" by [[Charlemagne]] is often mentioned as the historical standard for the ''Strausswirtschaft''. It enabled winemakers to sell their own products free of business tax. The ''Strausswirtschaft'' (''Strauss'' – German for bunch of flowers; ''Wirtschaft'' – pub, inn) had to be marked as such by a bunch of flowers put up at the entrance.
Typical dishes offered are rather simple and rich. Regional specialities are for instance: [[File:Spundekaes-Bachus-1.jpg|thumb|''Spundekäs'' with pretzels]] [[File:WeckWorschtWoi1.jpg|thumb|''Weck, Worscht un Woi'']] * ''[[Schlachtplatte]]'' (black pudding, [[liverwurst]] and [[sauerkraut]]) * ''Spundekäs'' in [[Rheinhessen (wine region)|Rhenish Hesse]] and the [[Rheingau (wine region)|Rheingau]] * ''Weck, Worscht un Woi'' in Rhenish Hesse, the Rheingau and the [[Palatinate (region)|Palatinate]] * ''Pfälzer [[Saumagen]]'' (Palatine sow’s stomach) * ''[[Maultasche]]n'' (Swabian pockets) with potato salad * ''Winzerteller'' (sausage and cheese dish) * ''[[Wurstsalat]]'' (sausage salad) * ''[[Zwiebelkuchen]]'' (onion pie) * ''Flammkuchen'' ([[Tarte flambée]]) * [[Bratwurst]] and [[Kraut]] * ''Blaue Zipfel'' (in [[Franconia]]) * Dressed [[Camembert (cheese)|Camembert]] (in Franconia) * ''Kuhkäs'' (in Franconia - a cheese dish)
Elaborate dishes are not allowed.
==Legal aspects==
Almost nowhere are ''Strausswirtschaften'' considered restaurants, which means that owners do not need a concession. Nevertheless, the trade office needs to be notified in advance about the period during which the ''Stausswirtschaft'' intends to sell food and drink.<ref>[http://www.kommunal-web.de/formulare/bundesrecht/133006.pdf Anzeige des Betriebs einer Straußwirtschaft]</ref> Although ''Strausswirtschaften'' do not need a licence, there are certain laws they have to follow. Among other things, a ''Strausswirtschaften'' is not allowed to offer lodging or engage in trade. Food and beverage must be served at the place of production. It is forbidden to rent any extra facilities for serving food and beverage. The following rules need to be respected:
* Selling food and drink is limited to four months a year * The opening times can be divided into two periods. * There is a maximum capacity of 40 seats. There are no rules, however, dictating the number of people permitted to squeeze in on the benches or likewise the number of people allowed to stand around drinking their wine. Exception: In [[Rhineland-Palatinate]] there is no limit on the number of seats.<ref>[http://bundesrecht.juris.de/gastg/__14.html Gaststättengesetz § 14 Straußwirtschaften]</ref> *A minimum of hygiene has to be considered and is subject to public control * Strausswirtschaften are only allowed to serve very simple dishes. Hot sausages and loin ribs with sauerkraut are given as such an example in the regulations as well as coffee and cake. * [[Beer]] and other alcoholic beverages (excluding wine) must not be served. Home distilled spirits, however, are allowed. Alongside wine and/or [[cider]] at least one non-alcoholic drink has to be offered. Tap water is explicitly excluded.<ref>[http://www.forstexperten.de/Besteuerung.pdf Besteuerung der Land- und Forstwirtschaft]</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Wine|Food}} * [[Heuriger]] * [[German wine]] * [[German cuisine]]

{{reflist}}
[[Category:Restaurants by type]] [[Category:Restaurants in Germany]] [[Category:Types of drinking establishment]] [[Category:Wine terminology]] [[Category:German wine]]

{{About|synaeresis in linguistics|syneresis in chemistry|syneresis (chemistry)}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Sound change}} In [[linguistics]], '''synaeresis''' ({{IPAc-en|s|ɪ|ˈ|n|ɛ|r|ə|s|ɪ|s}}; also spelled '''syneresis''') is a phonological process of sound change in which two adjacent vowels within a word are ''combined'' into a single syllable.{{cite book|last=Trask|first=R. L.|title=The Dictionary of Historical and Comparative Linguistics|year=2000|publisher=Edinburgh UP|location=Edinburgh|page=333|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EHeGzQ8wuLQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=snippet&q=333&f=false}} The opposite process, in which two adjacent vowels are pronounced separately, is known as "[[Hiatus (linguistics)|diaeresis]]". For any given word, speakers generally hold a traditional view about the ''standard'' pronunciation of that word. When realized in a careful reading style, each particular word is associated with this single, ''standard'' phonetic form.{{cite web|last=Laporte|first=Eric|title=A Formal Tool for Modelling "Standard" Phonetic Variations|url=http://www.isca-speech.org/archive_open/archive_papers/ppospst/pp91_039.pdf|work=ISCA Archive|publisher=ESCA Workshop on Phonetics and Phonology of Speaking Styles|accessdate=19 April 2013}} However, each word also possesses multiple non-standard or reduced phonetic forms which are produced in a greater range of contexts.{{cite web|last=Laporte|first=Eric|title=A Formal Tool for Modelling "Standard" Phonetic Variations|url=http://www.isca-speech.org/archive_open/archive_papers/ppospst/pp91_039.pdf|work=ISCA Archive|publisher=ESCA Workshop on Phonetics and Phonology of Speaking Styles|accessdate=19 April 2013}} These multiple variations in the pronunciation of a single word are referred to as allophonic variants. To classify one of these other forms as an allophonic variant of a word means that pronouncing the word in this way will not change the intended meaning of the word.{{cite web|last=Laporte|first=Eric|title=A Formal Tool for Modelling "Standard" Phonetic Variations|url=http://www.isca-speech.org/archive_open/archive_papers/ppospst/pp91_039.pdf|work=ISCA Archive|publisher=ESCA Workshop on Phonetics and Phonology of Speaking Styles|accessdate=19 April 2013}} Synaeresis is one of various phonological processes in which segments of words or phrases are lost. The general term for a loss of sound segments in the field of linguistics is known as "[[elision]]".{{cite book|last=Trask|first=R. L.|title=The Dictionary of Historical and Comparative Linguistics|year=2000|publisher=Edinburgh UP|location=Edinburgh|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EHeGzQ8wuLQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=snippet&q=333&f=false}} Other types of elision include the processes of [[apheresis (linguistics)|apheresis]], [[Syncope (phonetics)|syncope]], [[apocope]], [[synizesis]], and [[synaloepha]].{{cite book|last=Trask|first=R. L.|title=The Dictionary of Historical and Comparative Linguistics|year=2000|publisher=Edinburgh UP|location=Edinburgh|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EHeGzQ8wuLQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=snippet&q=333&f=false}} ==Etymology== Synaeresis comes from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] {{lang|grc|συναίρεσις}} (''synaíresis''), a "contraction", a "taking ''or'' drawing together",{{LSJ|sunai/resis|συναίρεσις|ref}}. from {{lang|grc|συναιρέω}} (''synairéō''), "(I) contract", "(I) grasp ''or'' seize together",{{LSJ|sunaire/w|συναιρέω|shortref}}. derived from {{lang|grc|[[wikt:σύν|σύν]]}}, "with",{{LSJ|sun|σύν|shortref}}. and {{lang|grc|[[wikt:αἱρέω|αἱρέω]]}}, "(I) grasp, seize".{{LSJ|ai(re/w|αἱρέω|shortref}}. Semantically, it is easy to understand how this term evolved historically. The term eventually becamer applied to a process in which vowels are taken or drawn together. ==English== Synaeresis often occurs with [[reduced vowel]]s in [[English language|English]], as in [[Asia]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|eɪ|z|i|ə}} → {{IPAc-en|ˈ|eɪ|ʒ|ə}}) and [[Sebastian (disambiguation)|Sebastian]] ({{IPAc-en|s|ə|ˈ|b|æ|s|t|i|ə|n}} → {{IPAc-en|s|ə|ˈ|b|æ|s|tʃ|ə|n}}). ==French== Synaeresis is a common process in [[French language|French]]. For example, the French word ''louer,'' which means ‘to praise,’ is typically pronounced as [lwe] according to transcriptions using the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]].{{cite web|last=Laporte|first=Eric|title=A Formal Tool for Modelling "Standard" Phonetic Variations|url=http://www.isca-speech.org/archive_open/archive_papers/ppospst/pp91_039.pdf|work=ISCA Archive|publisher=ESCA Workshop on Phonetics and Phonology of Speaking Styles|accessdate=19 April 2013}} That pronunciation reduces the [u] vowel to a [w], or a [[Semivowel|glide]] sound, when pronounced in conjunction with the [e] vowel sound. In this example, the standard pronunciation uses the process of synaeresis to compress both of the original vowel sounds into one syllable. However, when speakers are asked to produce this word in a more controlled situation, in a careful reading style, French speakers often produce extended forms or different allophonic variants for the word.{{cite web|last=Laporte|first=Eric|title=A Formal Tool for Modelling "Standard" Phonetic Variations|url=http://www.isca-speech.org/archive_open/archive_papers/ppospst/pp91_039.pdf|work=ISCA Archive|publisher=ESCA Workshop on Phonetics and Phonology of Speaking Styles|accessdate=19 April 2013}} These forms of the word include [lue] according to IPA transcriptions, in which the two vowels are pronounced separately using the process of diaeresis.{{cite web|last=Laporte|first=Eric|title=A Formal Tool for Modelling "Standard" Phonetic Variations|url=http://www.isca-speech.org/archive_open/archive_papers/ppospst/pp91_039.pdf|work=ISCA Archive|publisher=ESCA Workshop on Phonetics and Phonology of Speaking Styles|accessdate=19 April 2013}} ==Greek== ===Ancient Greek=== In [[Ancient Greek]], synaeresis{{refn|group=n|Note on terminology:
In ancient books in Greek, vowel contraction in general, including synaeresis and [[crasis]], is often called ''crasis'' or is analysed into various classes using related terms.{{OED|crasis}}}} is the merging and pronunciation of two separate vowels as a [[diphthong]] (e.g. α + ι → αι {{IPA|/ai̮/}}) or a [[Vowel length|long vowel]] (e.g. ο + ο → ου {{IPA|/ο:/}}); a characteristic example of this is the [[Grammatical conjugation|conjugation]] class or classes of [[Ancient Greek grammar (tables)#Contracted verbs|contracted verbs]] ({{lang-grc-gre|συνῃρημένα}} – or {{lang|grc|περισπώμενα – ῥήματα}}). [[Diaeresis (prosody)|Diaeresis]] on the other hand, is the separation of a diphthong into two vowels (αϊ {{IPA|/a.i/}}). Certain words in Proto-Indo-European had two vowels separated by the consonant ''s'' or ''y'' (''esu'' "good"). In Greek, this consonant changed to ''h'' (''ehu''), and was lost between vowels (''eu''). In [[Homer]], the two vowels were sometimes pronounced separately (diaeresis: {{lang|grc|ἐΰ}}) and sometimes together (synaeresis: {{lang|grc|εὖ}}). Later in [[Attic Greek]], they were always pronounced together. In Greek synaeresis, two vowels merge to form a long version of one of the two vowels (e.g. ''e'' + ''a'' → ''ā''), a diphthong with a different main vowel (e.g. ''a'' + ''ei'' → ''āi''), or a new vowel intermediate between the originals (e.g. ''a'' + ''o'' → ''ō''). Contraction of ''e'' + ''o'' or ''o'' + ''e'' leads to ''ou'', and ''e'' + ''e'' to ''ei'', which are in this case [[spurious diphthong]]s. In general, the accent after contraction copies the accent before contraction. Often this means circumflex accent. But for nouns, accent follows the nominative singular. Sometimes this means a different accent from the uncontracted form — i.e., whenever the ending has a long vowel. Contraction in Greek occurs throughout the present and imperfect of contracted verbs and in the future of other verbs. There are three categories based on the vowel of contraction: ''a'', ''e'', or ''o''. ====Verbs==== {| style="border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; margin: 1em 1em 1em 0;" |- | style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | '''''a''-contract''':
"honor" {| |- | τιμ'''άω''' || → || τιμ'''ῶ''' |- | τιμ'''άει'''ς || → || τιμ'''ᾷ'''ς |- | τιμ'''άει''' || → || τιμᾷ |- | τιμ'''άο'''μεν || → || τιμ'''ῶ'''μεν |- | τιμ'''άε'''τε || → || τιμ'''ᾶ'''τε |- | τιμ'''άου'''σι || → || τιμ'''ῶ'''σι |} | style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | '''''e''-contract''':
"love" {| |- | φιλ'''έω''' || → || φιλ'''ῶ''' |- | φιλ'''έει'''ς || → || φιλ'''εῖ'''ς |- | φιλ'''έει''' || → || φιλ'''εῖ''' |- | φιλ'''έο'''μεν || → || φιλ'''οῦ'''μεν |- | φιλ'''έε'''τε || → || φιλ'''εῖ'''τε |- | φιλ'''έου'''σι || → || φιλ'''οῦ'''σι |- |} | style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | '''''o''-contract''':
"think right" {| |- | ἀξι'''όω''' || → || ἀξι'''ῶ''' |- | ἀξι'''όει'''ς || → || αξι'''οῖ'''ς |- | ἀξι'''όει''' || → || ἀξι'''οῖ''' |- | ἀξι'''όο'''μεν || → || ἀξι'''οῦ'''μεν |- | ἀξι'''όε'''τε || → || ἀξι'''οῦ'''τε |- | ἀξι'''όου'''σι || → || ἀξι'''οῦ'''σι |- |} |- |} ====Nouns==== Contraction also occurs in nouns, including the [[Ancient Greek nouns#Contracted second declension|contracted second declension]]. {| style="border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; margin: 1em 1em 1em 0;" |- ! colspan = 2 | "bone" |- | style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | '''singular''' {| |- | ὀστ'''έο'''ν || → || ὀστ'''οῦ'''ν |- | ὀστ'''έου''' || → || ὀστ'''οῦ''' |- | ὀστ'''έῳ''' || → || ὀστ'''ῷ''' |- |} | style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | '''plural''' {| |- | ὀστ'''έα''' || → || ὀστ'''ᾶ''' |- | ὀστ'''έω'''ν || → || ὀστ'''ῶ'''ν |- | ὀστ'''έοι'''ς || → || ὀστ'''οῖ'''ς |- |} |- |} ''S''-stem nouns undergo contraction with vowel endings. {| style="border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; margin: 1em 1em 1em 0;" |- style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | ''-es'' stem || ''-os'' stem |- style="border: 1px #aaa solid;" | {| |- | {{lang|grc|γένος}} ||   || no contraction |- | {{lang|grc|γένεος}} || → || {{lang|grc|γένους}} |- | {{lang|grc|γένεϊ}} || → || {{lang|grc|γένει}} |- | {{lang|grc|γένεα}} || → || {{lang|grc|γένη}} |- | {{lang|grc|γενέων}} || → || {{lang|grc|γενῶν}} |- | {{lang|grc|γένεσσι}} ||   || no contraction |- |} | {| |- | {{lang|grc|αἰδώς}} ||   || no contraction |- | {{lang|grc|αἰδόος}} || → || {{lang|grc|αἰδοῦς}} |- | {{lang|grc|αἰδόϊ}} || → || {{lang|grc|αἰδοῖ}} |- | {{lang|grc|αἰδόα}} || → || {{lang|grc|αἰδῶ}} |- |} |- |} Some [[compound (linguistics)|compound]] nouns show contraction: * {{lang|grc|λειτ'''ο-ε'''ργίᾱ}} → {{lang|grc|λειτ'''ου'''ργίᾱ}} "[[liturgy]]" ===Modern Greek=== In Modern Greek, where original diphthongs are pronounced as monophthongs, synaeresis is the pronunciation of two vowel sounds as a [[monophthong]], and diaeresis is the pronunciation of the two vowels as a diphthong (αϊ {{IPA|/ai̮/}}).{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} ==See also== *[[Diaeresis (prosody)|Diaeresis]] *[[Metaplasm]] **[[Synalepha]] ***[[Crasis]] ***[[Elision]] ****[[Contraction (grammar)|Contraction]] ***[[Synizesis]] *[[Smoothing (phonetics)]] ==Notes and references== ===Notes=== {{reflist|group=n}} ===References=== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Figures of speech]] [[Category:Phonetics]] [[Category:Poetic devices]]

{{distinguish|Voro language}} {{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=October 2015}} {{disputed|date=October 2015}} }} {{Infobox language |name = Võro |nativename = ''võro kiil'' |states = [[Estonia]] |region = Southern [[Estonia]] |ethnicity = [[Võros]] |speakers = {{sigfig|87,000|2}}, including Seto |date = 2011 census |ref = {{Cite web |url=http://pub.stat.ee/px-web.2001/Dialog/varval.asp?ma=RLE07&lang=2 |title=Eesti Emakeelega Püsielanikud Murdekeele Oskuse Ja Soo Järgi, 31. Detsember 2011 |publisher=[[Statistikaamet]], Pub.stat.ee |language=Estonian |access-date=2014-08-23}} |familycolor = Uralic |fam2 = [[Finnic languages|Finnic]] |fam3 = [[South Estonian language|South Estonian]] |dia1 = [[Seto dialect|Seto]] |agency = [[Võro Institute]] (semi-official) |iso3 = vro |glotto=none |map = voromkaart.jpg |mapcaption = Võro language area — ''Võromaa'' (Võro county) in its historical boundaries between Tartu and Seto areas, Russia (''Vinnemaa'') and Latvia (''Lätimaa'') |notice = IPA }} [[File:South Estonian today.PNG|thumb|South Estonian today. Võro is marked with dark red colour.]] [[File:Võro valdo kaupa.jpg|thumb|Percentage of Võro speakers in Estonian municipalities according to the Estonian census 2011]] [[File:Speakers-of-South-Estonian-2012.png|thumb|According to the [[2011 Estonia Census]] there were 101,857 speakers of South Estonian: 74,499 speakers of Võro, 12,549 Seto speakers, 9,698 Mulgi speakers, 4,109 Tartu speakers and 1,002 other South Estonian speakers.]] [[File:Estonian-Voro-bilingual-parish-sign.JPG|thumb|A bilingual Estonian-Võro parish sign in [[Võrumaa]]. The parish name with [[vowel harmony]] (Urvastõ) is in Võro.]] [[File:Vromaa-turismiteedus.jpg|thumb|A Trilingual (Estonian–English–Võro) sign of a tourist information center in [[Võru]]]] [[File:Abckiraoppus.jpg|thumb|A 1998 [[ABC-book]] in Võro language written by [[Sulev Iva]], [[:fiu-vro:Kauksi Ülle|Kauksi Ülle]] etc.: "ABC kiräoppus"]] '''Võro''' ({{lang-vro|võro kiil{{`}}|links=no}} {{IPA|[ˈvɤro kʲiːlʲ]}}, {{lang-et|võru keel}}){{cite web|url=http://www.iub.edu/~bafsa/articles.html#Voro |title=Recent Events |publisher=Iub.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eki.ee/cgi-bin/mkn8.cgi?form=lg&lang=et&kohanimi=98002344&f2v=Y&f3v=Y&nimeliik=&maakond=&vald=&kihelkond=&asum=&f10v=Y&f14v=Y&of=tb |title=Päring LINGUAE andmebaasist. Keelte nimetused |publisher=Eki.ee |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23}} is a language{{cite web|url=http://www-01.sil.org/iso639-3/documentation.asp?id=vro|title=ISO 639 code sets |publisher=Sil.org |date=2009-01-16 |accessdate=2014-08-23}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.ethnologue.com/language/vro |title=Võro |date=2015 |website=Ethnologue |access-date=2015-12-09}} belonging to the [[Finnic languages|Finnic branch]] of the [[Uralic languages]].{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/chris.html |title=Endangered languages in Europe and North Asia |publisher=Helsinki.fi |date=1980-09-13 |accessdate=2014-08-23}} Traditionally, it has been considered a dialect of the [[South Estonian language|South Estonian dialect group]] of the [[Estonian language]], but nowadays it has its own literary language{{cite web |url=http://dspace.utlib.ee/dspace/bitstream/10062/4860/1/iva_sulev.pdf# |title=Võru kirjakeele sõnamuutmissüsteem (Inflectional Morphology in the Võro Literary Language) |author= Sulev Iva, Phd at [[Tartu University]], (English summary pp 144–146) |publisher=Dspace.utlib.ee}} and is in search of official recognition as an [[wikt:autochthonous|autochthonous]] [[regional language]] of Estonia.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecmi.de/fileadmin/downloads/publications/JEMIE/2012/KoreinikSaar.pdf |format=PDF |last=Koreinik |first=Kadri |title=Maintenance of South Estonian Varieties: A Focus on Institutions |publisher=Journal on Ethnopolitics and Minority Issues in Europe |date=2012 |accessdate=2015-12-09}}{{cite web|url=https://fedora.phaidra.univie.ac.at/fedora/get/o:127464/bdef:Content/get |last=Meiorg |first=Marianne |title=Legal and Institutional Framework Analysis: Seto and Võro languages |publisher=Working Papers in European Language Diversity 19 |date=2012 |accessdate=2015-12-09}} Võro has roughly 75,000 speakers ([[Võros]]) mostly in southeastern Estonia, in the eight parishes of the historical [[Võru County]]: [[Karula Parish|Karula]], [[Hargla Parish|Harglõ]], [[Urvaste Parish|Urvastõ]], [[Rõuge Parish|Rõugõ]], [[Kanepi Parish|Kanepi]], [[Põlva Parish|Põlva]], [[Räpina Parish|Räpinä]] and [[Vastseliina Parish|Vahtsõliina]]. These parishes are currently centred (due to redistricting) in Võru and [[Põlva County|Põlva]] counties, with parts extending into [[Valga County|Valga]] and [[Tartu County|Tartu]] counties. Speakers can also be found in the towns of [[Tallinn]] and [[Tartu]] and the rest of Estonia.{{cite web|url=http://wi.ee/index.php/welcome?lang=en- |title=Võro Instituut » Welcome! |publisher=Wi.ee |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23}}{{Cite web |url=https://wi.ee/en/voro-language/ |title=Võro language |last=Saar |first=Evar |website=Võru Instituut |language=en-US |access-date=2014-08-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.omniglot.com/writing/voro.htm |title=Võro language and alphabet |publisher=Omniglot.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23}} ==History== Võro is a descendant of the old [[South Estonian]] regional language and is the least influenced by Standard Estonian (which is based on Northern Estonian dialects).{{cite web|url=https://phaidra.univie.ac.at/detail_object/o:308890?SID=76572&actPage=2&type=listview&sortfield=fgs.createdDate,STRING&sortreverse=0 |last=Koreinik |first=Kadri |title=Võro kiil|publisher=Studies in European Language Diversity 23.2 |date=2013 |accessdate=2015-12-09}} Võro was once spoken further south and east of historical Võromaa in South Estonian-speaking enclaves Lutsi, Leivu and Kraasna in what is now [[Latvia]] and [[Russia]]. In addition to Võro, other contemporary variants of South Estonian include the [[South Estonian language|Mulgi]], [[Tartu language|Tartu]] and [[Seto dialect]]. One of the earliest written evidences of South Estonian is a translation of the [[New Testament]] (''Wastne Testament'') published in 1686. Although the status of South Estonian began to diminish after the 1880s, the language began to undergo a revival in the late 1980s.{{cite web|url=https://phaidra.univie.ac.at/detail_object/o:308888?SID=76572&actPage=1&type=listview&sortfield=fgs.createdDate,STRING&sortreverse=0 |last=Koreinik |first=Kadri |title=The Võro language in Estonia: ELDIA Case-Specific Report |publisher=Studies in European Language Diversity 23 |date=2013 |accessdate=2015-12-09}} ==Present situation== The majority of Estonians perceive the Võro language as a modern synonym for South Estonian.{{cite web |url=http://www.sgr.fi/sust/sust258/sust258_pajusalu.pdf |format=PDF |last=Pajusalu |first=Karl |title= The reforming of the Southern Finnic language area. The Quasquicentennial of the Finno-Ugrian Society. Suomalais-Ugrilaisen Seuran Toimituksia = Mémoires de la Société Finno-Ougrienne 258 |location= Helsinki |year=2009 |pages=95–107}} Today, Võro is used in the works of some of Estonia's best-known playwrights, poets, and authors ([[Madis Kõiv]], [[Ülle Kauksi]], [[Jaan Kaplinski]], [[Ain Kaalep]], etc.). One newspaper is printed in Võro: the fortnightly ''[[Uma Leht]]'' (literally 'Our Own Newspaper'). 26 public schools offer weekly special classes (mostly [[extracurricular activities|extracurricular]]) in modern Võro. Estonia's contribution to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004]] was the song "[[Tii]]", which was performed by [[Neiokõsõ]] in Võro. The language is endangered,{{cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/culture/languages-atlas/en/atlasmap/language-id-422.html |title=UNESCO Atlas of the World's Languages in danger |publisher=Unesco.org |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23}} and according to Kadri Koreinik this is due to the government's lack of legal commitment to protect the language. ==Orthography== Võro employs the [[Latin script]], like Estonian and Finnish. {| cellpadding="4" style="margin:auto; text-align:center;" |- |[[А]]

{{IPA|/◌ʲ/}} |} Most letters (including ''ä'', ''ö'', ''ü'', and ''õ'') denote the same sounds as in Estonian, with a few exceptions. The letter ''q'' stands for the [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/ʔ/}} and ''y'' denotes {{IPAslink|ɨ}}, a vowel very close to [[Russian language|Russian]] ''ы'' or [[Polish language|Polish]] ''y'' (from 2005 written ''õ''). [[Palatalization (phonetics)|Palatalization]] of consonants is marked with an [[acute accent]] (´) or [[apostrophe]] ('). In proper typography and in handwriting, the palatalisation mark does not extend above the [[cap height]] (except uppercase letters ''Ń'', ''Ŕ'', ''Ś'', ''V́'' etc.), and it is written above the letter if the letter has no [[Ascender (typography)|ascender]] (''ǵ'', ''ḿ'', ''ń'', ''ṕ'', ''ŕ'', ''ś'', ''v́'' etc.) but written to the right of it otherwise (''b’'', ''d’'', ''f’'', ''h’'', ''k’'', ''l’'', ''t’''). In computing, it is not usually possible to enter these character combinations or to make them look esthetically pleasing with most common fonts, so the apostrophe is generally placed after the letter in all cases. This convention is followed in this article as well. ==Phonology== ===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" | ! colspan="2" | [[Front vowel|Front]] ! colspan="2" | [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! {{small|unrounded}} ! {{small|rounded}} ! {{small|unrounded}} ! {{small|rounded}} |- ! Close | | {{IPA link|i}} | {{IPA link|y}} | {{IPA link|ɨ}} | {{IPA link|u}} |- ! Mid | {{IPA link|e̞|e}} | {{IPA link|ø̞|ø}} | {{IPA link|ɤ̞|ɤ}} | {{IPA link|o̞|o}} |- ! Open | {{IPA link|æ}} | | {{IPA link|ɑ}} | |} ====Vowel harmony==== Võro has preserved the system of [[vowel harmony]] that was present in [[Proto-Finnic]].{{clarify|reason=Võro seems to have more vowels than Proto-Finnic. Didn't it add more vowels to the vowel harmony system of Proto-Finnic?|date=February 2016}} This distinguishes it from Estonian and some other Finnic languages, which have lost it. The vowel harmony system distinguishes front, back and neutral vowels, much like the system found in Finnish. A word cannot contain both front and back vowels; suffixes automatically adapt the backness of the vowels depending on the type of vowels found in the word it is attached to. Neutral vowels can be combined with either type of vowel, although a word that contains only neutral vowels has front vowel harmony. The only neutral vowel is ''i'', like in [[Votic language|Votic]] but unlike Finnish and Karelian, where ''e'' is also neutral. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Võro vowel harmony ! ! Front ! Back |- ! Close rounded | y | u |- ! Close unrounded | colspan="2" | i |- ! Mid rounded | ø | o |- ! Mid unrounded | e | ɤ |- ! Open | æ | ɑ |} The vowel ''y'' is considered a back vowel for harmony purposes, but does not participate in harmony itself, as it does not occur in suffixes and endings. Some examples, with Estonian and Finnish included for comparison: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Võro ! Estonian ! Finnish ! Meaning |- | kül'''ä''' | küla | kyl'''ä''' | village |- | küs'''ü'''n'''ü'''q | küsinud | kys'''y'''n'''y'''t | has asked |- | hõb'''õ'''h'''õ'''n'''õ''' | hõbedane | hopeinen | silver |} ===Consonants=== {| class="wikitable" |- !
